EDL: 克罗马侬人是智人中的一支，生存于旧石器时代晚期。原来是指发现于法国西南部克罗马侬石窟里的一系列化石，现在的则包含迁入欧洲以前的早期智慧人种在内。 1868年3月，地质学家路易·拉尔泰在法国多尔多涅省埃齐耶的克罗马侬石窟里发现了5具骨骼遗骸。其中的模式标本是一颗颅骨，被命名为“克罗马侬1号”。

EDL: Dr. D. Tyler McQuade became deputy director of DARPA’s Defense Sciences Office (DSO) in January 2017. For more than three years prior to that appointment, Dr. McQuade was a DARPA program manager leading a number of programs in the molecular sciences including ACDC, Battlefield Medicine, Biofuels, Fold Fx, LoCo, and Make-It. While each of these programs has molecular features, most also nurture his interests in biology, complexity, applications of AI to the physical sciences, and metrology. Dr. McQuade has also developed small-scale efforts in materials and data sciences.

Prior to joining DARPA in August 2013, Dr. McQuade was a professor of chemistry. During his 15-year academic career, he published more than 80 manuscripts, patents and book chapters on topics ranging from catalysis to macromolecules to pharmaceutical agent synthesis. In collaboration with professors from Virginia Commonwealth University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Dr. McQuade started the Medicines for All Initiative, funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which reduced production costs of a variety of anti-viral compounds including the AIDS medicine nevirapine. Dr. McQuade received numerous awards during his academic career including the Beckman Young Investigator and MIT Technology Review Innovators Under 35. In addition, Dr. McQuade was a visiting group leader at the Max Planck Institute of Colloids and Interfaces and a visiting professor in the Food and Nutrition Toxicology Department at the ETH-Zurich.

Dr. McQuade received a doctorate degree in chemistry from the University of Wisconsin and a Bachelor of Science in chemistry and Bachelor of Science in biology from the University of California, Irvine. He was a National Institutes of Health Post-Doctoral Fellow at MIT prior to starting his independent research career.
